comment: Enjoy the scotch. I would say it is a bit more oily than the profile suggests. I think if it was aged longer it may have more of a lingering taste. As it is the taste is gone within a minute.

Nose: Caramel and vanilla. Reminds me of smelling the forest. Taste: Initially smoky with a small bite, but gives way to burnt wood and possibly ginger. More smoky and spicy to me than fruity and sweet. I added one ice cube to mine.
Sweet... Might be a step for me to try bourbon...
Citrusy without being overly fruity. Great value buy.

An improved Auchie starter scotch. Received my bottle as a Christmas gift. Smooth vanilla cream nose with similar taste with hints of coconut and lemony apricot. The finish offers a sugary peach sensation with a mild, welcome spice. I recommend this if you're a scotch lover wanting to delve into bourbon or vice-versa.
Mild, fruity, some spice, no smoke, tasty.
This is a bit more oily in a Scotch than I'm used to. The hint of vanilla stays on your tongue, and the citrus washes out throughout.

I sometimes wonder about the professional reviews I read.  This professional reviews says it has coconuts tastes.  Damned if my palet can taste it.

The write up says it was aged in used Bourbon Barrels...  I can't really taste that influence.  I suspect the barrels had a light char and were used less than six years.

In summary it's a somewhat expensive entry level scotch.

Honey, vanilla, and OOOAAAKKK, on the nose. Sweet at first sip with an "am I drinking scotch, or sucking on staves?" Finish.  It is good, but has very little complexity.  Enjoyed, but will not buy again.

Great mild starter whisky. Some fruit or vanilla on the nose.

10/28/17 - In Edinburgh on Tour - Helena notes some cinnamon on this. Smooth with a drop or two of water.
Light, bright and goes down easy. A hint of smoke and citrus. Really nice scotch for the price.
A great gateway scotch for avid bourbon enthusiasts afraid of taking their first steps into the scotch world. The vanilla sweetness of a bourbon with the smokey bite of a scotch.
Vanilla and lemon on the nose. Quite sweet, vanilla on the tongue.  Soft, easy finish with a hint or spicy burn
Slight twinge of vanilla, other then that quite a mellow and easy to drink whiskey.

Nose: Coconut water, tangy like BBQ/sweet and sour sauce. 
Palate: Little vanilla, little orange rind, light milk chocolate.

It's time to kick off the third wave of samples from our Scotch trade team.  This one was supplied by my friend Ryan, and it continues the theme he established back in the very beginning:  scotch that is similar to bourbon.  This one strays a bit from that line, but the heavy vanilla and oak notes fall right in line.

The smell is very inviting- soothing vanilla, lots of soft floral notes and a hint of herbal citrus.  The taste is very oaky.  Lots and lots of oak.  Not too harsh.  There is the typical lowland-style delicacy in place here, though.  

The palate is very lightly charred oak spice with just the right amount of cinnamon and heat.  It's delightfully smooth through the entire sip, while the finish is pretty short.

It's solid.  It's light.  It's ridiculously drinkable.  It's a great pre-dinner dram on a warm, late summer evening.  I'd even enjoy this one as a kick starter to a tasting event.  Thanks, Ryan.  3.5 stars.  Cheers.
Not a bad entry level Scotch for Bourbon drinkers. I really get more of a Bourbon taste in it than Scotch.

Lowland sample from Scotch Whisky Experience. 
Much sweeter than the three wood.

The nose is tart and unremarkable (even in a glencairn and after a great deal of patience), with surface-level hints of unripe berries and young spirit. The palate is more rambunctious, angsty even: sharp vanilla, perfumed and floral, with underwhelming flavors of rock candy and fruit overpowered by heavy menthol and barrel spice. The mouthfeel is waxy and the aftertaste is that of cherry chapstick. Seedbread comes along after the pleasant raspberry zing finish that happens to accompany that spicy palate. I see some nice Lowland characteristics at play, but only clumsily — not as in the sure simplicity of a Glenkinchie. Overall one of the least luxurious scotch experiences I've had. Maybe the bottle that Kory got was an anomaly.
Very light in flavour. Good to ease people into whisky

Nose: fruity, woody and clean citrus. 
  Taste: lots of sweet vanilla up front, then lemon and other fruits before the oak takes over. 
Finish: medium finish with very pleasant oak and some citrus.
  A very decent Lowland whisky with mediocre complexity but an excellent price-quality ratio.
Lowland single malt. Too much vanilla for me.
Hint of coconut, woody, easy to drink with a short linger.

Not bad for the price. Very easy drinking. Bright gold in color. No alcohol burn whatsoever! Says bourbon vanilla but don't pick up at all. Lots of citrus and the white peach comes through. Would recommend for an everyday Scotch but wouldn't recommend as the best.
Another excellent Auchentoshan. More fruity and sweet than the 12 year, very distinct. A great unique, light, and flavorful scotch.

Color : Pale gold with moderate legs - very cool wide shaped bottle
Nose: I get vanilla, pecans, and cider notes
Palate: strong vanilla, bourbon of course, oak, cinnamon or nutmeg, sweet fruit 
Finish: smooth, warming and fairly long for a light 40% ABV - a very enjoyable Lowland dram
An easy sipper single malt you could enjoy anytime, and very reasonably priced
Very light with vanilla, honey and some coconut on the nose and palate. Little to no finish. Friendly chap, all in all, but you'd think first fill barrels would make a more flavorful whisky.
Vanilla, lemon, and a buttery consistency on dilution
Rather insipid. Tastes like a watered down blend of Jack Daniels and Johnnie Walker Red. Do not try it with ice or a bit of water. It just disintegrates.
Good for the price ($34). I could drink it often, but there is better out there.
The influence of the bourbon barrel is evident, though AO isn't as sweet as typical bourbon (thankfully). A little alcohol burn. Tasty, not heavy.
10/2016 at Hook & Ladder with Charles Hsiao. Easy to drink, inoffensive, but raw oak sticks out, unbalanced, oddly odd.  Would not buy.
Nice fruity floral whiskey and fun to order

My first try at Scotch. Good Smokey flavor with with vanilla and some cinnamon, but not too overwhelming. I really like the citrus zest that is distinguishable from the other flavors without being overkill. Very smooth.

Going by the description, on the box, I expected something really good from this juice.  On the nose I could smell...a little sweetness, but not much else.  On the palate, the main flavor was wood (not a bad thing) and a slight fruity sweetness...but not much.  The whole experience felt "muted" like there was some filter blocking the smells and flavors from coming through.  This was so mild, it was almost flavorless. 
  
  The spirit does not need water, it just dilutes it more.  It does benefit with a little rest time in the glass, but not a lot.  Very bland, nothing unique.  I will not buy this one again.
Surprisingly plain and boring. Not memorable.
Very light. Lots of vanilla. A little too weak. Easy to drink, but not an interesting flavor.

Visual:  In the glass it is a medium amber color/gold color. Medium, lasting legs after a swirl.

Nose:  Floral, and a mite tart, with hints of vanilla and toffee, as well as lemon zest and orange peel. Light and crisp.

Palate: More citrus zest appears on the palate, along with some sweetness and vanilla. It is light and thin, which might be owing to many factors, including the mild 40% ABV, the lack of maturity (I’m guessing), and the lowland triple distillation process. 

Finish:  The finish is short, with a bittersweet dark chocolate note and some barrel char. 

Empty glass:  Little to report.

This is a smooth and drinkable whisky. A great beginner’s scotch, or scotch intro for bourbon drinkers. It lacks challenge and complexity, but is nice and inoffensive. It would be a 3-1/2 star dram at a higher price point. At less than $40 USD, I’m bumping it to 4 stars.
Had it at the distillery near Glasgow. Pretty good. No peat so not smoky. Close to a bourbon.

I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I was quite surprised. This is a very pleasant whisky, though incredibly fragile - I would not recommend adding water. The nose hits all the right notes , but not necessarily what you expect from American oak. Sure there's vanilla and the ever so faint touch of wood, but lemon and apple are also both present, making this fruity rather than floral.  In these respects it could almost pass for a distant cousin of Jack Daniels. The palate is pleasant and quite smooth, though also flat and a little weak. The finish... It just isn't there. All in all a nice dram, especially for a novice.
Very tasty, I hope to add to my collection soon

Nose: 
From the bottle the smell is almost nothing. Benefits from time in the glass. Woody yet sweet but very mild
Taste: 
Wood, Peat, vanilla and almost a chocolatey aftertaste. Tiny hints of citrus
Summary: 
Very mild, but certainly drinkable, and for £20 a bottle it's definitely not going to tip the flavour to price ratio balance out of favour

Dare I say this reminds me of a Macallan 12? Keep this one neat, mint, right out of the box, my friends. Much different than the first Auchentoshan I tried, which was the Three Wood. Nosing this is really a pleasant experience, because I can already tell things to come will be balanced. Faint light citrus, a good dose of vanilla wafers, and spice. The palate is not too delicate, but sweet. A nice mouth-feel, medium coat, with buttery goodness, oak, and peach cobbler with french vanilla ice cream. Hell yes. The finish is medium, but I am far from bitching about that. This one is "Peaceful Easy Feeling" by the Eagles. Get some! 3.75. Thanks for the sample Ryan!

Nose: fruity, woody and clean citrus. 
  Taste: lots of sweet vanilla up front, then lemon and other fruits before the oak takes over. 
Finish: medium finish with very pleasant oak and some citrus.
  A very decent Lowland whisky with mediocre complexity but an excellent price-quality ratio.

First tasted at Revival, Clayton. 21-oct-2017. Really enjoyed it. Smell fresh cut lumber. Much warmer than Glenlivet 12 yr. Thick caramel. Cigar finish.  Malty. 
Smokey. Peaty.

A sample provided by Ryan as part of our Scottish distillery trading.  This is probably the 2nd or 3rd Auchenstoshan I've had, and all have been fairly young.  Light and creamy, but you can tell its youth by that certain bite on the palette and finish.  Even though it's triple distilled, it's very unlike its Irish cousins across the sea.  Really good as an intro whisky to the white wine drinker.  I'm curious to try this distillery at the older ages like 18'or 21.  Wondering if more of the creamy fruity character comes out then?

fruity, warm, smooth, lingering taste.
bourbon similarity

Stop number 33 on the Scottish Distillery Tour is Auchentoshan. This is my first scotch from the Lowland region so I had a certain level of anticipation and excitement headed into this review. This single malt is bottled at 40% ABV, has colorant added making it a golden straw color, and it is chill filtered. 

The nose is young and lively. Full of underripe pears, green oak and toasted coconut. Malty, barley sugar sweetness, vanilla, toffee and light cinnamon. It's grassy, like a mix of fresh green grass and dry brown grass. Some creamy citrus notes, like lemon cheesecake and a little grapefruit. This really reminds me of an unpeated version of the Bowmore Gold Reef. There is a touch of green apples and honey. A little mint and anise in the background. There are some bourbony notes. It I find them to be quite muted. 

Vibrant and fresh on the palate. Coconut, vanilla cream. Pears and honey, cinnamon, toffee and nutmeg. More green oak. Pepper, not much but more than I expected. Definitely a young whisky and it shows. 

Light to medium bodied and on the thin side. 
The finish is medium length, dry, oaky and a tad green. 

There is much more personality here than I expected but I believe that to be due to its youth. The fact that it's triple distilled reinforces that belief. I would love to try the 21 year old to see what a properly matured Lowland whisky has to offer. This is a good scotch, but it's immature to a fault. I'm not sold on Auchentoshan, but neither am I condemning them based on this one sample. Speaking of which, thank you to Ryan (Lee) for providing this sample. 3.25 seems accurate, especially for the low price of $35. 
Cheers
Complex and spicy, with some peat and nearly no smoke. Sweet, but balanced

Had some business out of town, so I grabbed a few samples to work my way through.  Sadly, I only got to sample this one (the other nights were sampling with workmates at larger volumes...)

The nose, straight out, is fruity with banana, tangerines and coconut.  Sprinkle in notes of tea and honey, vanilla and pinch in some cinnamon.  All this is clean, crisp and creamy.

The mouthfeel is extremely thin and light, unlike the nose.  Citrus lemon, cinnamon and oak char come through, but a vanilla sugar sweetness are immediate but fades just as rapidly.  A short-lived palate and almost right to a finish.

What remains is short with vanilla, white pepper, lemon zest with a touch of oak.

This is akin to an Irish whiskey (sensible give the near proximity to Norther Ireland).  The sweetness, the fruity banana and thin body (triple distillation).  The brevity and thinness take away from it's full potential.  Increasing the ABV to 43% or better yet 46% would greatly improve this whisky.  Give this time, like one should, and the whisky-reward is improved.  The longer it sits, the more improved it gets, though, only to a certain point.  [85/100][Tasted: 12/4/17]

I bought this after trying the 12 year but this is not anything close. It’s deceptive on the nose promising you a good time, but it’s ugly on the palette. The aftertaste is...not as bad, but still left me thinking how I’m going to get rid of the rest of the bottle!
Nose is pleasant and oaky.  Taste isn’t as smooth as one would think.  No true notes other than oak.  I enjoy a sweeter scotch though.  This isn’t bad, just no real character.
Очень стандартный, через чур "бурбоновый", тяжеловатый - не смог пить чистым. Как по мне - сугубо коктейльный вариант. Но для коктейлей я лучше возьму Grant's.

The taste that was there was good. However, it was lighter.. or maybe cleaner tasting than I would like and  there wasn't the lingering oily taste that I would prefer in a good scotch. A good entry to scotch I would say.

Light, floral nose, lemon and zest, maybe ginger?
Slight spice and hints of smoke. 
Short to medium finish. Some acidity.
Great showcase of wood barrel flavor

Creamy but thin on flavour. Oak, mild honey and faint fruit sweetness and a suggestion of smoky depth. The foundation of a good dram is there but that’s it. Not bad but it leaves me looking for more. $57 in Ontario.
Didn't care for this Scotch because it was not smoky or peaty. The experts say if you like bourbon you will like this Scotch. I like bourbon, but found this Scotch too sweet for my taste.
light and poppy with primarily cinnamon, nutmeg, and oak

Some poor quality casks did this young single malt no favors. The 40% ABV and loads of caramel color didn’t help either. Picked up a bottle on sale for $27 and felt I paid too much. Very disappointing single malt and it is unlikely I will pay money to sample the rest of their range.
very mild, practically no burn. light charcoaled wood after taste
Utrolig nem begynder whisky. Ikke noget ekstra særligt spændene eller ekstra ordinært.
Alt for mild, ikke de store karakter,
An after taste I did not enjoy
Not bad for the cost, better chilled
Golden caramelized colour, dried apricot, milk chocolate, cinnamon. 8/10
Might get a boost from the Aero Club Bar atmosphere in San Diego. Nice little whisky.

Sehr leicht, karamellig im Abgang

Pot Still Glasgow, 4/18. Bestellt von Vera

Would rate zero stars if I could. This tastes like wet, mouldy cardboard. Just awful. Even their bland, uninteresting 12 Year Old is a step up from this absolute mess. How on earth any honest person could award this garbage 87 points is beyond me. For the same money, you could get an excellent bourbon or at least a Glenfiddich 12, which is not life-changing, but is at least pleasant. This is the only whisky I’ve ever poured down the drain. Luckily, I didn’t buy a bottle. My friend poured it for me on 3 separate occasions, and my reaction was the same each time. So was his. He ended up dumping the bottle. It’s really that bad.
Lots of vanilla, sweetness and light in colour. Very easy to drink with minimal bite but a citrus tang to finish.
Scotch Whisky Experience: 3.5. Pro note says full gold, vanilla and citrus zest, creamy vanilla and coconut with a little spice. I say short finish, smooth, everyday drinkable
Light and simple.  Entry whisky.  Prefer to Glenevit, not to morangie or fiddich.
This is one of my favorites. It’s my every day drinker.
Very delicate, quite woody and sweet. Also great in cocktails
Vanilla, citrus zest and a bit of spice. Has a bourbony vibe for a Scottish whisky.
heavy oak, cinnamon on the finish, black pepper, subtle smoke
simple, oaky, gentle, plenty of wood. pleasant
vinilla front with a sweet hint of coconut
Coconut. Peach. Smoke. Ginger. Lemon zest. Vanilla. Cinnamon.
scotch. peppery nose. smooth, fruity tongue. long finish. definitely get a bourbon style mouthy feel and flavor. strange but delicious
Easy to drink, floral and sweet but not too much
Fine, sweet, soft, subtle fruity and vanilla flavors but light and unremarkable
I lied. The 12 year is a little smoother and I think I prefer it.
Vanilla, oak, and with a hint of smoke. Wonderfully balanced, with all of the flavors mingling perfectly. Love it.
Light acidic taste. Buttery, bright smells. Simple flavors
Light and smooth hints of Carmel and chocolate. Light, less complex initially could smell chocolate and caramel. Water brought out fire but decrees complexity
Rather like a more dry, more citrus version of Stranahan's.
Rather like a drier slightly citrus version of Stranahan"s.

Another offering from the only Lowland Scotch distillery I've tried to date. On sale for $30 a bottle, this purchase was a no-brainer. 

There's a good amount going on in the nose. I get coconuts and orange initially. There's also a certain grassy note present, as well as the aroma of dried fruit. A nice nose. 

On the palate, I get more of the coconut as well as notes of tangerine and vanilla. I get a strong oak flavor, which is no doubt a product of bourbon barrel aging. The finish fades very quickly. At this point, I'm left only with the orange/tangerine note. This is probably due in part to the low ABV.

Overall, the American Oak does a fine job as a role-player in the Auchentoshan line-up. It's a solid entry level whisky and offers great value for your money. It's not all that complex, and it certainly is not a game-changer. But at its price point, it's there's nothing to complain about. I'd say this one is worth a buy for anybody seeking a budget single malt. Good stuff.
lovely easy going dram. Plenty of cinnamon, vanilla. not a huge amount of depth but bloody good value.

I’m still trying to understand this dram. Is it boring or does it perfectly embody the unique character of the lowlands the way it is supposed to? Initially underwhelmed, the gentle nature of this dram caught up with me and body-slammed me onto the soft grasses of the northern Lowlands. Oaky, sweet, full of vanilla and cinnamon, at first you think there’s very little finish until you realize lying in a meadow chewing on a piece of grass for 10 minutes IS the finish. I loved it.
мягкий, очень питкий, с нотами сладких фруктов

Nose: Orange skin, vanilla, dried prunes, some oakiness
Palate: Vanilla, orange, slight but pleasant bitterness
Finish: Zesty orange skin, peppery, slight creaminess from vanilla
Residue in the glass: Strong dried prunes
Light. Not a lot of flavor. Wouldn't get again but it was ok.

Coconut on the nose along with something I couldn’t before describe (until I read other reviews calling it old banana). It smells like a banana cream pie my dad used to make where he would use overripe bananas. I don’t dislike it but it’s definitely odd. Palate is on the thin side and a bit hot for 80 proof. Brown banana flavor lingers on the finish with a substantial amount of oak. It’s an odd one for sure. I don’t hate it but won’t be buying another bottle. I’d say it was worth a one time $35 expenditure and will keep it around for friends to try as it is at least unique.
Solid oak flavor, slight hint of vanilla
Fruity. No gas. Easy. But nothing to write home about. Forgettable.
You can definitely taste the bourbon influence. It’s sweet with hints of Cinnamon and vanilla. I am not a big fan of Scotch but this is a good choice for Bourbon fans. It’s a nice change of pace.
Similar to the 12. Didn’t find a lot of differences actually

I tried 3 Auchentoshan whiskeys during whiskey festival. All of them were ok, but there was something exceptional in this one that made me come back to it. Not a wonder, but definitely worth trying. [JG2018]

I was eager to try this since it is the only Lowland distillery available in NC, and now that I'm about to finish the bottle I can say this was disappointing. At $40 this is not worth an initial buy before you try it first. Unfortunately the only other bottle I can get is the Three Wood at $70. I imagine that is better. The American Oak has a subtle noise of muted oil and vanilla wood with an oily taste that immediately disappears. In fact, everything on the taste kind of disappears instantly. I don't get any real bourbon characteristics, and hardly any of the nose that is suggested by the expert reviewer. Maybe my novice self can't pick out a lot of the subtleties, but I do know I've had Scotch at this price that is much better.
Floral and thin.  Water would destroy this.  It’s nice but not robust in any way.
Delicious. Rest went into the infinity bottle
Sweet, bourbon like front, charred ginger finish
Mild peat.  Smooth through.  Oaky finish.  Very good
Oak and apple. Nice balance to the home bar. Makes me curious of other older  expressions from this distilleries.
I thought this one somewhat simple and rough.
Found this to be rather one dimensional.  Would not buy again.

This is a complex taste for me. When I sip this without much attention, I don’t enjoy it much. The combo of spice, tartness, and sweetness can be distracting. However, when I drive this intentionally and appreciate the journey of flavors this dram offers, I enjoy it more. Still though, not something I purchase over something else, given the choice.

not too sweet. orangy, vanilla.
finishes darker, almost like chocolate, with some spice.
this stuff really tastey

Well, quite unusual. 
Somewhat like wooden dust and grass, fermented grapes, tons of citrus zest and notes of polish there to the nose. But the aroma is not strongly marked - it is some kind of very viscid but not pronounced.
Again some polish, zest and acetone to the tongue. Sherry and spirit notes on a palate and on the edges of a tongue. After some time it gives pleasant sweetness. Not very gentle whiskey (to say it right) and not very usual. Not very complex though but weird.
Finish is again with chemical notes, some spirit, bitter citrus zest too.
So, after the first acquaintance I have to say - there are two main taste components which are vanilla sweetness and polish/zest. It remains weird to me and I did not like it much personally but something’s in it.
Quite the enjoyable scotch that made me investigate the Auchentoshan lineup more thoroughly. A little pricier option for the everyday dram but does not disappoint.
Light. Vanilla and fresh fruits on the nose. More vanilla and lemon/citrus tang on palate.  Short lived, light fruity finish.

Nose: very subtle. Hard to find. Allergies are bad, however so maybe it’s just me. Picking up notes of vanilla and oak.

Taste: Sweet and woody. Oak and vanilla with hints of coconut and a clean citrusy finish. Has a somewhat oily mouthfeel and quick finish.

nose: toffee. when added water, dried grass (hay?).
mouth: spicy toffee, dried grass. smoke, upon comparison to a truly not-smoky whiskey

Very oaky and vanilla on the nose.

Tried it with some ice to melt and open the flavor as I sip.

Felt almost too sweet. Lots of vanilla still and hints of coconut with cinnamon and some citrus.

Can’t figure out if it’s oily or not. Doesn’t seem to slowly slip down the side of the glass but feels oily on the tongue.

Feels like it can’t make up it’s mind between bourbon or scotch. Underwhelmed this time, but I have a whole bottle so I’ll keep trying.
Very mellow, nice for dipping with a drop of water.
Forward spice, smoky middle and finish; fairly smooth, actually
great scotch for a beginner that enjoys bourbon,  it's a nice scotch that has some bourbon qualities

Nose: Maple Syrup akin to Finished Rye Angels Envy
Palette: Dry cedar, vanilla, raw alcohol, and Demerara Sugar
This is not the worst scotch I’ve ever had. It tastes watered down a little. It’s oily and unremarkable
Aug 2019 w/ Eric @ The Last Hurrah. sweeter than Auchentoshan 3 wood. smokey? some bite. oak?
Probably doesn't fully deserve the four but its rather smooth, not harsh. Not much flavor either.
A spicy punch as it first hits the tongue followed by sweet fruit notes and a vanilla finish. A tablespoon of spring water opens up the flavors and takes the overpowering spiciness.

Oakiness, perfume on the nose
Mintiness and green fruit. Very subtle on the taste
Burn and alcoholic aftertaste
It’s good. Reminds me of a standard Irish, but with a bit more body. Definitely oaky. It’s like a marriage between a bourbon and an Irish.

Interesting combination of scotch and bourbon qualities. Sweet, pleasant nose with cinnamon and fruit at the front. Add a drop of water to bring out the smoky tastes. Fuller than an Irish, but with similar sweet palate notes. Great value for the money.
Not a bad dram just not to my taste at all. Nose is interring full of vanilla and fresh fruit palate filled with tropical notes pineapple and coconut. Finish is short lived and sweet.
Sweet spice with notes of Flan
Smooth, easy to drink, slight tea taste

Nose: vanilla, bourbon influence
Pallets: raspberry upfront, then vanilla and orange and sweet grain on the back
Sweet, smooth, and a delightful lemony taste on the way down

Vanilla and cream with hints of butterscotch and brown sugar on the nose. 

First taste is almost bitter but it quickly mellows out to a sweet and fruity finish with mild spice. A moderate warmth with a quick linger.

Nose: coconut, vanilla, citrus peel
Palate: vanilla and citrus
Finish: oak
Smooth and easy to drink. Large vanilla note with an orange finish.

Bought this on a whim (always on the lookout for a solid “every day” dram).  It’s not bad.  I really like the nose a lot...very woody with citrus notes.  The flavor is nice (you definitely get the vanilla from the bourbon cask), though lighter than most whiskies.  Finishes with a lingering burn and then a faint bitterness.  So in short, starts strong and diminishes from there, but never quite falls down.  It’s good, but there are better at this price range (Old Pulteney 12 comes to mind).

I tried to like this, I really did, but it tastes like it had potential, but was pulled from the barrel far to early. It has overpowering ethanol, with only a hint of the barrel it was sourced from. Too bad, even at its price, there are far better options
Really easy to drink. Spicy and a little sweet but not overly so, maybe because of the tartness. Tea notes.
Warming, mulled spices, bits of ginger
Not too smoky very smooth and sweet with lots of oak. Very nice for sipping! Highly recommend especially for the lower price.

Cinnamon throughout. Great value. Sweet and smooth. 

$10 per pour
McCormacks Whisky Grill
07.02.19
Vanilla, citrus, very sweet and delicious. Long finish.

Nose: Linseed oil, turpentine (wood, not mineral), cod liver oil, tinned peaches, hay, some fleeting citrus aromas and a hint of barrel.

Palate: An oily and slightly oaky arrival with stone-fruit notes. Some vanilla, cocoanut, chilli and more oak presence come through in the development. The texture is a little thin but there is a slight creaminess.

Finish: Short. Mildly spicy with oak tannins and a resinous sweet aftertaste.

I don't find any great resemblance to bourbon here at all - this is much more like a heavily-oaked Irish blend without the unmalted barley notes. Actually, it's pretty representative of the Auchentoshan house style in general - resinous and citric spicy. The nose improves a little when it's left to rest in the glass, but the palate never loses it's gauche youthful buzz.

Not a very exciting malt but it's inexpensive, mixes well with dry ginger ale, and is comparable to a mid-range blended scotch.

"Average" : 2.5 stars
Stronger than anticipated. Good. Spicier than palette lends to.
Nose: Bourbon, then lemon. Taste: oily, spiced.
Harsh with not much flavor to balance.
Smooth with a strong oak profile...like the name implies

Light Caramel and oak on the nose. Hard to get much other than that. The palate matches the nose, but it has a little more heat than I’d like. Not the kind of heat you get from a high proof, but the kind of heat you get from an unrefined whiskey, that sits on your tongue. It plays well with the American oak, and finishes with a bit of smoke, uncharacteristic of a non-peated scotch. It’s decently tasty and, for the price, a great buy.
Slightly sweet, definitely floral, but not bitter. It's ok. Possible buy in a tertiary purchase
As a bourbon fan, I enjoyed the light burn on the sip. Sweet scent but doesn’t overpower. It’s single malt scotch with a bourbon finish.

N: Tropical, Light. 
P: Lemon, biscuit. 
Finish: Slight spice.
Very nice single malt. Sweet, vanilla, and oak are most prominent flavors.
Hints of peat but nothing really unique about this scotch. Just tastes like a scotch.
If a single malt isn't anyhow adventurous then what's the point? Nutty oakiness is not enough to justify dulling triple distillation.
Good for single malt, but nothing interesting... maybe because of the triple distillery.
Overall nice flavor. Easy to drink.
smooth and floral. Nice sipping whisky
Light and enjoyable with a hint of smoke on the end. Not huge in flavor, and light bodied, it is unobtrusive and easy to sip.
Spice, cinnamon on the nose, a bit thin.
Toasty malt with some lemon curd and warm cloves
Smooth, hints of orange and almost coconut taste.
Got it on sale for $40. Tough to beat that

K - jasny,olej
N - dab, kwiaty, alkohol
S - alkoholowy, delikatny, dab, drewno, skora, rodzynki
F - srednio dlugi, alkoholowy, drewniany
Wood flavors initially with floral finish.
Nicer on the second attempt. Quite an odd taste - maybe fruity?

The color is light gold, nice and transparent. Sweet nose with caramel, vanilla and floral notes. There are really much oak in nose and even in taste. Taste is simple, but in general balanced, with nice long heating finish. One of the most smoothest, light and drinkable I've ever taste. During the blind degustations it always gets on my top. Nice original laconic bottle design. Summary: a great buy for this price, for those who likes sweet and non-smoky scotches.
A very nice oaky dram. Not very complex but a enjoyable drink
Decent standard whisky, similar to tamnavulin

My first lowland! Since it was basically between this and Glenkinchie, where the difference is like $50... 

The nose on this is unlike anything I've smelled in a scotch whisky; fruity yet floral, with lychee and heavily perfumed rose petals. There is a distinct whiff of banana pudding that somehow blends naturally into the rest. This just may be the prettiest smelling whisky ever. It has the gentlest entry, like a breeze, very sweet, with coconut and vanilla cream, bananas foster topped with cinnamon, stopping just short of rum-like. It finishes with just the vaguest suggestion of grassy hay and lemony tea leaves.

The novelty wears off after a while though (probably the unusual coconut note), and I ended up using the last part of the bottle to make a few "Bobby Burns" a.k.a. the "Scottish Manhattan". I can't wait to try other lowlands though, particularly Ailsa Bay, if it ever decides to release a dedicated single malt stateside - or maybe just the Three Wood of this because the pickin's are quite slim.
Nice. A bit harsh, but tasty af.

It smells of blonde wood and alcohol, with maybe a tad of fresh orange. It smells like new flooring. The flavor is just a mess. So much mineral with a bland wood backing. Gross bread for sure. Wood and a bit of smoke, but mostly just alcohol. Blech! There are bits of spices and vanilla mixed in there, but it's all middled and none of the flavors are executed well. There is sufficient sweetness, but it doesnt really help. It tastes worse than Glenlivet 12, which is around the low bar for drinkability. This is really not worth drinking.
Warm sweet vanilla mouth feel. Burns a bit smoke on the back end.
Very shallow hint of fruit.  Bad aftertaste
Drinkable with a good bit of water. Chemical nose and taste.
American oak très vanillé j’adore! Très doux!

I have learned, that i am not an Auchentoshan fan. If im blinded i would even think of it as any 12yo irish whisky. This one is smooth as any other Auchentoshan (because it is triple distilled). Not bad, but you can certainly get something else for your money.

Bottled at 40%abv 

On the nose, i got grassy notes, plum and the purest malted barley. 

On the palate is oily, a little oak burn with almonds. Mostly malty. Aftertaste is short- medium with ginger spice. 

Overall this is your average whisky, 71 over 100.
